paragraphs.text:
%md
# About This Lab
**Objective:** Become familiar with dataframes schemas operations.
Create and save DataFrames using different types of data sources. 
Learn options for inferring and defining schemas.
**File locations:**
    Exercise files: /home/training/training_materials/devsh/exercises/dataframes
    Data (local): /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/devices.json
    Data (HDFS): /devsh_loudacre/devices.json
    Hive table: devsh.accounts
**Successful outcome:**
**Before you begin:**
**Related lessons:** Working with Dataframes and Schemas

---

msg.data:
About This Lab

Objective: Become familiar with dataframes schemas operations.
Create and save DataFrames using different types of data sources.
Learn options for inferring and defining schemas.

Data (local): /home/training/training_materials/devsh/data/devices.json
Data (HDFS): /devsh_loudacre/devices.json
Hive table: devsh.accounts

Successful outcome:
Before you begin:
Related lessons: Working with Dataframes and Schemas

%md
# Lab
---

msg.data: Lab

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Create a Dataframe Based on a Hive Table

msg.data: Create a Dataframe Based on a Hive Table

paragraphs.text:
%md
The %sql magic provides you with a Spark SQL environment that allows you to interact with Hive tables.

msg.data: The %sql magic provides you with a Spark SQL environment that allows you to interact with Hive tables.

paragraphs.title: 1 - Review the schema of the devsh.accounts table
paragraphs.text: %sql

paragraphs.text: %pyspark

Print the schema and the first 10 rows of the DataFrame, and note that the schema aligns with that of the Hive table.

paragraphs.title: 3 - View the dataframe and confirm alignment with the Hive table
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
Create a new DataFrame with rows from the accounts data where the zip code is 94913, and save the result to CSV files in the /devsh_loudacre/ accounts_zip94913 HDFS directory. 
You can do this in a single command, as shown below, or with multiple commands.

%md
### Optional: 
Try creating a new DataFrame based on the CSV files you created above. 
Compare the schema of the original accountsDF and the new DataFrame. What’s different? 
Try again, this time setting the inferSchema option to true and compare again.

paragraphs.text: %pyspark

### Define a Schema for a DataFrame
If you have not done so yet, review the data in the HDFS file /devsh_loudacre/devices.json.

Define a Schema for a DataFrame

paragraphs.title: 7 - Review the data in /devsh_loudacre/devices.json
paragraphs.text: %sh

%md
Create a new DataFrame based on the devices.json file. (This command could take several seconds while it infers the schema.)

msg.data: Create a new DataFrame based on the devices.json file. (This command could take several seconds while it infers the schema.)

paragraphs.title: 8 - Read the devices.json file into a devDF dataframe
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
View the schema of the devDF DataFrame. Note the column names and types that Spark inferred from the JSON file. 
In particular, note that the release_dt column is of type string, whereas the data in the column actually represents a timestamp.

msg.data:
View the schema of the devDF DataFrame. Note the column names and types that Spark inferred from the JSON file.
In particular, note that the release_dt column is of type string, whereas the data in the column actually represents a timestamp.

paragraphs.title: 9 - View the schema of the devDF dataframe
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
Define a schema that correctly specifies the column types for this DataFrame. 
Start by importing the package with the definitions of necessary classes and types.
Next, create a collection of StructField objects, which represent column definitions. 
The release_dt column should be a timestamp.

```spark
from pyspark.sql.types import *
devColumns = [ StructField("devnum",LongType()), StructField("make",StringType()), StructField("model",StringType()), StructField("release_dt",TimestampType()), StructField("dev_type",StringType())]
```

msg.data:
Define a schema that correctly specifies the column types for this DataFrame.
Start by importing the package with the definitions of necessary classes and types.
Next, create a collection of StructField objects, which represent column definitions.
The release_dt column should be a timestamp.

from pyspark.sql.types import *
devColumns = [ StructField("devnum",LongType()), StructField("make",StringType()), StructField("model",StringType()), StructField("release_dt",TimestampType()), StructField("dev_type",StringType())]

paragraphs.title: 10 - Define a schema
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

paragraphs.title: 11 - Create a schema (a StructType object) using the column definition list
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

paragraphs.title: 12 - Recreate the devDF DataFrame, this time using the new schema
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

paragraphs.title: 13 - View the schema and data of the new DataFrame, and confirm that the release_dt column type is now timestamp
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
Now that the device data uses the correct schema, write the data into Parquet format, which automatically embeds the schema. 
Save the Parquet data files into an HDFS directory called /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet.

msg.data:
Now that the device data uses the correct schema, write the data into Parquet format, which automatically embeds the schema.
Save the Parquet data files into an HDFS directory called /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet.

paragraphs.title: 14 - Save the devDF dataframe to /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet using the parquet format
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md
### Optional: 

Use parquet-tools to view the schema of the saved files. First download the HDFS directory (or an individual file), then run the command.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -get /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet /tmp/ 
$ parquet-tools schema /tmp/devices_parquet/
```

In CDH 5, the parquet-tools command could be used directly on files in HDFS. In CDH 6, this is no longer the case. 
As a workaround, you can use: hadoop jar /opt/cloudera/parcels/CDH/jars/parquet-tools-1.9.0- cdh6.1.1.jar schema hdfs://localhost/devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet/. Related JIRA: CDH-80574.

Note that the type of the release_dt column is noted as int96; this is how Spark denotes a timestamp type in Parquet.
For more information about parquet-tools, run parquet-tools --help.

msg.data:
Optional:

Use parquet-tools to view the schema of the saved files. First download the HDFS directory (or an individual file), then run the command.

$ hdfs dfs -get /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet /tmp/ 
$ parquet-tools schema /tmp/devices_parquet/

In CDH 5, the parquet-tools command could be used directly on files in HDFS. In CDH 6, this is no longer the case.
As a workaround, you can use: hadoop jar /opt/cloudera/parcels/CDH/jars/parquet-tools-1.9.0- cdh6.1.1.jar schema hdfs://localhost/devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet/. Related JIRA: CDH-80574.

Note that the type of the release_dt column is noted as int96; this is how Spark denotes a timestamp type in Parquet.
For more information about parquet-tools, run parquet-tools –help.

paragraphs.title: 15 - Optional - Confirm the schema of the saved files using parquet-tools
paragraphs.text: %sh

%md
Create a new DataFrame using the Parquet files you saved in devices_parquet and view its schema.
Note that Spark is able to correctly infer the timestamp type of the release_dt column from Parquet’s embedded schema.

msg.data:
Create a new DataFrame using the Parquet files you saved in devices_parquet and view its schema.
Note that Spark is able to correctly infer the timestamp type of the release_dt column from Parquet’s embedded schema.

paragraphs.title: 16 - Optional - Read the parquet files back in a dataframe to confirm the schema is well saved
paragraphs.text: %pyspark

%md

# Solution

msg.data: Solution

paragraphs.text:
%md
### Create a Dataframe Based on a Hive Table

msg.data: Create a Dataframe Based on a Hive Table

paragraphs.title: 1 - Review the schema of the mine.accounts_info table
paragraphs.text:
%livy.sql

DESCRIBE mine.accounts_info

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

Spark Application Id: application_1612378464455_0002
Spark WebUI: http://master:8088/proxy/application_1612378464455_0002/

paragraphs.text:
%md
The Livy interprepter provides you with a Spark SQL environment that allows you directly to interact with Hive tables.
The %sql provides a SQL like environment allowing straight SQL commands.

This exercise usess a DataFrame based on the `account` table in the Hive database. 

Hive beeline CLI
beeline -u jdbc:hive2://localhost:10000 -e "DESCRIBE devsh.accounts"

msg.data:
The Livy interprepter provides you with a Spark SQL environment that allows you directly to interact with Hive tables.
The %sql provides a SQL like environment allowing straight SQL commands.

This exercise usess a DataFrame based on the account table in the Hive database.

Hive beeline CLI
beeline -u jdbc:hive2://localhost:10000 -e “DESCRIBE devsh.accounts”

paragraphs.title: 2 - Create a new DataFrame using the Hive devsh.accounts_info table
paragraphs.text:
%livy.pyspark

accountsInfoDF = spark.read.table("mine.accounts_info")

msg.data:
Spark Application Id: application_1612378464455_0002
Spark WebUI: http://master:8088/proxy/application_1612378464455_0002/

paragraphs.text:
%md
The `table` function uses a jdbc connection to locates the Hive metastore to pull
in schema information from the hive RDBMS database. This also passes the connect
string for HiveServer2 to the Spark driver.

msg.data:
The table function uses a jdbc connection to locates the Hive metastore to pull
in schema information from the hive RDBMS database. This also passes the connect
string for HiveServer2 to the Spark driver.

paragraphs.title: 3 - View the dataframe and confirm alignment with the Hive table
paragraphs.text:
%livy.pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Show the accounts data")
accountsDF.printSchema()
accountsDF.show(10)

table.tableOptionSpecHash: [{"name":"useFilter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable filter for columns"},{"name":"showPagination","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable pagination for better navigation"},{"name":"showAggregationFooter","valueType":"boolean","defaultValue":false,"widget":"checkbox","description":"Enable a footer for displaying aggregated values"}]

paragraphs.title: 4 - Create a new dataframe and save it to HDFS
paragraphs.text:
%livy.pyspark
#from pyspark.sql.functions import col

accountsDF.select("first_name", "last_name", "address", "city", "county", "state", ("web", "alias = website")).where("state = 'CA'").show()
#.write.option("header","true").csv("/mine/accounts_stateCA")

paragraphs.text:
%md
The `where` function is used to select rows. 

The `write` function is used to write data from Spark to HDFS. Spark will write to a large number of data formats.
Common data types include: .avro, .csv, .json, and .text

The `option` function will pass in parameters; such as `header` = true, to include the schema on the first row.

Create a new DataFrame with rows from the accounts data where the zip code is 94913, and save the result 
to CSV files in the /devsh_loudacre/ accounts_zip94913 HDFS directory.

msg.data:
The where function is used to select rows.

The write function is used to write data from Spark to HDFS. Spark will write to a large number of data formats.
Common data types include: .avro, .csv, .json, and .text

The option function will pass in parameters; such as header = true, to include the schema on the first row.

Create a new DataFrame with rows from the accounts data where the zip code is 94913, and save the result
to CSV files in the /devsh_loudacre/ accounts_zip94913 HDFS directory.

paragraphs.title: 6 - Optional: study the impact of the inferSchema option
paragraphs.text:
%livy.pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Read a csv file: no options")
spark.read.csv("/mine/accounts_stateCA").printSchema()

sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Read a csv file: header=true")
spark.read.option("header","true").csv("/mine/accounts_stateCA").printSchema()

sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Read a csv file: header=true inferSchema=true")
spark.read.option("header","true").option("inferSchema","true").csv("/mine/accounts_stateCA").printSchema()

paragraphs.text:
%md
No options assigns an alphanumeric sequence to all fields and casts all fields as data type string.

Header = true will assign field names but will cast all fields as data type string.

Header = true, Infer Schema = true will assign filed names and assign data types.

msg.data:
No options assigns an alphanumeric sequence to all fields and casts all fields as data type string.

Header = true will assign field names but will cast all fields as data type string.

Header = true, Infer Schema = true will assign filed names and assign data types.

### Define a Schema for a DataFrame
If you have not done so yet, review the data in the HDFS file /devsh_loudacre/devices.json

Define a Schema for a DataFrame

If you have not done so yet, review the data in the HDFS file /devsh_loudacre/devices.json

paragraphs.title: 8 - Read the devices.json file into a devDF dataframe
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Read the devices.json file")
devDF = spark.read.json("/devsh_loudacre/devices.json")

%md
Create a new DataFrame based on the devices.json file. (This command could take several seconds while it infers the schema.)

paragraphs.text:

devDF.printSchema()
devDF.show(5)

paragraphs.text:
%md
View the schema of the `devDF` DataFrame. Note the column names and types that Spark inferred from the 
JSON file. In particular, note that the `release_dt` column is of type `string`, whereas the data in 
the column actually represents a timestamp.

msg.data:
View the schema of the devDF DataFrame. Note the column names and types that Spark inferred from the
JSON file. In particular, note that the release_dt column is of type string, whereas the data in
the column actually represents a timestamp.

paragraphs.title: 10 - Define a schema
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

from pyspark.sql.types import *

devColumns = [ 
    StructField("devnum",LongType()), 
    StructField("make",StringType()), 
    StructField("model",StringType()), 
    StructField("release_dt",TimestampType()), 
    StructField("dev_type",StringType())
    ]

%md
Define a schema that correctly specifies the data types for each column of this DataFrame. 

Start by importing the package with the definitions of necessary classes and types.

A `StructField` object is used to define the field name and the data type.
A schema is defined as a collection of `StructFields`.

Next, create a collection of `StructField` objects, which represent column definitions. 
The `release_dt` column should be a timestamp.

```spark
from pyspark.sql.types import *
devColumns = [ StructField("devnum",LongType()), StructField("make",StringType()), StructField("model",StringType()), StructField("release_dt",TimestampType()), StructField("dev_type",StringType())]
```

msg.data:
Define a schema that correctly specifies the data types for each column of this DataFrame.

Start by importing the package with the definitions of necessary classes and types.

A StructField object is used to define the field name and the data type.
A schema is defined as a collection of StructFields.

Next, create a collection of StructField objects, which represent column definitions.
The release_dt column should be a timestamp.

from pyspark.sql.types import *
devColumns = [ StructField("devnum",LongType()), StructField("make",StringType()), StructField("model",StringType()), StructField("release_dt",TimestampType()), StructField("dev_type",StringType())]

paragraphs.title: 11 - Create a schema (a StructType object) using the column definition list
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

devSchema = StructType(devColumns)

%md
Create a schema (a `StructType` object) using the column definition list.

msg.data: Create a schema (a StructType object) using the column definition list.

paragraphs.title: 12 - Recreate the devDF DataFrame, this time using the new schema
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Read the devices.json file with a schema")
devDF = spark.read.schema(devSchema).json("/devsh_loudacre/devices.json")

paragraphs.title: 13 - View the schema and data of the new DataFrame, and confirm that the release_dt column type is now timestamp
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

devDF.printSchema()
sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Show the devices DataFrame")
devDF.show(5)

paragraphs.title: 14 - Save the devDF dataframe to /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet using the parquet format
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Write the devices DataFrame in parquet format")
devDF.write.parquet("/devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet")

%md
Now that the device data uses the correct schema, write the data into Parquet format, which automatically embeds the schema. 
Save the Parquet data files into an HDFS directory called /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet.

msg.data:
Now that the device data uses the correct schema, write the data into Parquet format, which automatically embeds the schema.
Save the Parquet data files into an HDFS directory called /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet.

paragraphs.title: 15 - Optional - Confirm the schema of the saved files using parquet-tools
paragraphs.text:
%sh

hdfs dfs -get /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet /tmp/
parquet-tools schema /tmp/devices_parquet/

%md
### Optional

Use `parquet-tools` to view the schema of the saved files. First download the HDFS directory (or an individual file), then run the command.

```shell
$ hdfs dfs -get /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet /tmp/ 
$ parquet-tools schema /tmp/devices_parquet/
```

In CDH 5, the parquet-tools command could be used directly on files in HDFS. In CDH 6, this is no longer the case. 
As a workaround, you can use: hadoop jar /opt/cloudera/parcels/CDH/jars/parquet-tools-1.9.0- cdh6.1.1.jar schema hdfs://localhost/devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet/. Related JIRA: CDH-80574.

Note that the type of the `release_dt` column is noted as `int96`; this is how Spark denotes a timestamp type in Parquet.
For more information about `parquet-tools`, run `parquet-tools --help`.

msg.data:
Optional

Use parquet-tools to view the schema of the saved files. First download the HDFS directory (or an individual file), then run the command.

$ hdfs dfs -get /devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet /tmp/ 
$ parquet-tools schema /tmp/devices_parquet/

In CDH 5, the parquet-tools command could be used directly on files in HDFS. In CDH 6, this is no longer the case.
As a workaround, you can use: hadoop jar /opt/cloudera/parcels/CDH/jars/parquet-tools-1.9.0- cdh6.1.1.jar schema hdfs://localhost/devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet/. Related JIRA: CDH-80574.

Note that the type of the release_dt column is noted as int96; this is how Spark denotes a timestamp type in Parquet.
For more information about parquet-tools, run parquet-tools --help.

paragraphs.title: 16 - Optional - Read the parquet files back in a dataframe to confirm the schema is well saved
paragraphs.text:
%pyspark

sc.setJobGroup("Working with DataFrames and schemas","Read the devices DataFrame in parquet format")
spark.read.parquet("/devsh_loudacre/devices_parquet").printSchema()

root
 |-- devnum: long (nullable = true)
 |-- make: string (nullable = true)
 |-- model: string (nullable = true)
 |-- release_dt: timestamp (nullable = true)
 |-- dev_type: string (nullable = true)

paragraphs.text:
%md
Create a new DataFrame using the Parquet files you saved in devices_parquet and view its schema.
Note that Spark is able to correctly infer the timestamp type of the release_dt column from Parquet’s embedded schema.

paragraphs.title: Additional resources
paragraphs.text:
%md
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

1. [Cloudera Tutorials](http://cloudera.com/tutorials.html) are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
2. [Cloudera Community](https://community.cloudera.com) is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
3. [Apache Spark Documentation](https://spark.apache.org/documentation.html) - official Spark documentation.
4. [Apache Zeppelin Project Home Page](https://zeppelin.apache.org) - official Zeppelin web site.

msg.data:
We hope you've enjoyed this lab. Below are additional resources that you should find useful:

  1. Cloudera Tutorials are your natural next step where you can explore Spark in more depth.
  2. Cloudera Community is a great resource for questions and answers on Spark, Data Analytics/Science, and many more Big Data topics.
